title: 104_s537
content:
The text chunk "SECTION 1. RATIFICATION OF CERTAIN CASWELL AND MONTANA CREEK NATIVE ASSOCIATIONS CONVEYANCES." is about ratifying conveyances made by certain Native associations in Caswell and Montana Creek. The conveyance of approximately 11,520 acres to Montana Creek Native Association, Inc., and Caswell Native Association, Inc., by Cook Inlet Region, Inc. in fulfillment of agreements from 1976 and 1982 is ratified as Federal law. The groups are declared to have received their full entitlement under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. This ratification does not affect the Act or the obligations of the United States. The ratification of the conveyance of land to Montana Creek Native Association, Inc. and Caswell Native Association, Inc. by Cook Inlet Region, Inc. is confirmed as Federal law. This does not involve any claims to land or money by these corporations or any other Alaska Native Corporation against the State of Alaska, the United States, or Cook Inlet Region, Incorporated. SEC. 2. MINING CLAIMS ON LANDS CONVEYED TO ALASKA REGIONAL CORPORATIONS. Section 22(c) of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to allow regional corporations to administer mining claims on lands conveyed to them. The Secretary will transfer administration of mining claims entirely within conveyed lands to the regional corporation. Holders of such mining claims must comply with general mining laws and federal land regulations. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act allows regional corporations to administer mining claims on conveyed lands. Holders of mining claims must comply with general mining laws and regulations. Any filings required for lands under Federal ownership must be made with the regional corporation. Contest proceedings and appeals will be handled in Federal District Court for the District of Alaska. Revenues from mining claims will be remitted to the regional corporation. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act allows regional corporations to administer mining claims on conveyed lands. Revenues from mining claims will be remitted to the regional corporation based on the proportion of the mining claim within the conveyed lands. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to address claims arising from contamination of transferred lands. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to address hazardous substances on lands transferred to Alaska Native Corporations. The Secretary must submit a report on the presence of contaminants within 18 months of enactment, after consulting with relevant parties. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to address hazardous substances on lands transferred to Alaska Native Corporations. The Secretary must submit a report on contaminants, potentially responsible parties, existing remedies, and recommendations for additional legislation within 18 months of enactment. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR RECONVEYANCES: Section 14(c) of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to authorize appropriations for technical assistance to Village Corporations for reconveyance requirements. Funds may be granted to ANCSA or nonprofit corporations with land planning capabilities. Section 1431(o) of the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act is amended to allow Arctic Slope Regional Corporation to acquire the subsurface estate beneath lands in the National Petroleum Reserve-Alaska selected by Kuukpik Corporation. This includes receiving a conveyance of reserved oil and gas rights subject to certain conditions. Arctic Slope Regional Corporation's entitlement to in-lieu subsurface lands under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act will be reduced upon receiving conveyance of oil and gas interests in the National Petroleum Reserve-Alaska. SEC. 6. REPORT ON OPEN SEASON FOR NATIVE ALASKA VETERANS' ALLOTMENTS. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with other relevant parties, must submit a report to Congress within 6 months of the enactment of the Act. The report will include the number of Vietnam era veterans eligible for but did not apply for land allotments, and an assessment of the potential impacts of additional allotments on conservation system units. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must provide relevant information to the Secretary of the Interior for a report to Congress. This report will include recommendations for any necessary additional legislation regarding land allotments on conservation system units. SEC. 7. TRANSFER OF WRANGELL INSTITUTE. Cook Inlet Region, Incorporated is authorized to transfer an approximately 10-acre site of the Wrangell Institute in Wrangell, Alaska, and structures to the United States. In exchange, property bidding credits totaling $382,305 will be restored to Cook Inlet Region, Incorporated's property account for immediate use. Cook Inlet Region, Incorporated will be defended by the United States in any claims related to ownership of land and structures before they are returned. SEC. 8. SHISHMAREF AIRPORT AMENDMENT.

The Shishmaref Airport, conveyed to the State of Alaska in 1967, may revert to the United States for nonuse. The Secretary can reacquire the airport and transfer it to the Shishmaref Native Corporation. Liability for cleanup of hazardous wastes remains with the State and potentially responsible parties, not the United States or the Corporation.
